Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultural Contexts of Mental Health Care

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Does the experience of mental illness vary across cultures? While the simple answer to this question is yes, how this happens turns out to be quite complex. On the one hand, there is evidence that mental health problems and patterns often emerge in similar ways across the world. Therefore, the psychiatric sciences argue for the use of diagnostic categories that are broadly applicable. On the other hand, anthropological research has found that mental illness manifests differently in different places, reflecting the social and cultural environment in which it is embedded. As researchers, policy-makers, and service users debate how social systems should best provide care for those who experience mental health crises, it is important to understand how such experiences are connected to social and cultural surroundings in order to assure that care is appropriate and effective. This is particularly important to contain costs. The market-based health care policies, medication-centered treatment plans, and dependence on hospital emergency rooms that are characteristic of mental health care in much of the Western world are costly and not always effective. As these approaches spread to other parts of the globe, it is urgent to know what works, what does not, and why.

These questions will be addressed in the research supported by this award. Washington University St. Louis anthropology doctoral candidate, Lauren Cubellis, with the guidance of Dr. Rebecca Lester, will investigate the idea that the experience of mental illness, specifically schizophrenia, is a complex interplay of multiple factors: heritable risk, traumatic history, social and economic context, and individual social relationships and resources. The researcher began her invesigation in New York City and with this award will extend it Berlin, Germany, which will allow her to understand the effects of cultural context on mental health and treatment outcomes. Berlin is a particularly apt site because German reunification has created a cultural context that markedly increases stress for some residents but not for others, offering a scientifically useful lens for comparison. The research will be conducted in a clinic that offers an option for care designed to reduce the numbers of people admitted to the psychiatric emergency room each year, and to improve the quality of life for people living with the symptoms of severe mental illness. Data will be collected with a mixed-methods approach, including participant observation, personal and professional history narratives, interviews, and archival research. These data will allow her to determine why this treatment model has been adopted in Berlin, how it relates to the history of Berlin as a fundamental center of psychiatric thought and knowledge production, and its potential spread as a plausible treatment option throughout Germany, Northern Europe, and the United States. Findings from the research will illuminate the role of history and socio-cultural context in the development and treatment of an apparently universal mental health syndrome. At the same time, it will provide information on a particular treatment model that may reduce costs and improve quality of life.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were to understand how historical processes have shaped the experience of psychiatric service provision in Germany, and the possibilities for innovative forms of care today. Of particular interest was the historical legacy of psychiatry under National Socialiam, as well as the post-war division of Germany. It was hypothesized based on preliminary research that these historical frames shaped treatment experiences into the present day, for both service-users and clinicians. A primary task of the project was to understand how contemporary institutions (economic, political, medical) shape possibilities for care in the present, and how historical experiences continue to emerge in present day practice.

The research focused on the implementation of a particular treatment model: Open Dialogue. This approach aims to keep patients out of the hospital, on low levels of medication, and connected to social networks of family and friends. Originally developed in Finland, the model has been used in Germany for more than 10 years and has demonstrated compelling effectiveness and cost-saving. Recent changes to insurance policy and economic landscapes have endangered the practice of this model, and a primary research question addressed the changes to daily practice under these circumstances.

The co-PI collected 28 personal history narratives from participating clinicians, as well 26 in-depths interviews with clinicians, clients, family members, and hospital and insurance personnel. The co-PI spoke with doctors working both in large hospital clinics, as well as community-based treatment centers, about the differences in possibilities for treatment across these different sites. The co-PI learned about the possibilties for institutional reform, and the means by which these are often constrained by hierarchy and cost. By speaking with providers in hospitals, in the community, insurance representatives, and service-users, she was able to successfully triangulate across these different vantage points to see how the distribution of resources shapes possibilities for treatment provision in the every day.

In addition to the goals outlined in the project proposal, the co-PI encountered new ways of engaging informants that were only possible as part of the broader ethnographic engagement in the field. Most significantly, she often served as a member of "the reflecting team" during meetings with clients. This involves providing a dialogical presence -- an additional voice, or perspective, that offers the possibilties for generative dissonance. The incorporation of many voices into treatment processes is an important part of this intervention, as it focuses on decentering monologic accounts of psychiatric crisis, and challenging hierarchical modes of authority. The co-PI has been extensively trained in this model, and was able to participate in reflecting sessions as a researcher/anthropologist. As an anthropologist/researcher, her unique position was a welcome addition to the dialogical process. 

Another additional research site that emerged with time in the field was training. The co-PI participated in over 340 hours of training for the Open Dialogue model. This was incredibly important, as it provided an opportunity to understand from close observation how it is clinicians learn to think with a different treatment approach, and what kinds of cultural beliefs shape treatment-as-usual. In order to learn to do this work requires a significant amount of un-learning. By participating in and observing training, the co-PI was able to learn about this process alongside new professionals. This access proved invaluable for better understanding the daily practice of Open Dialogue, and how clinicians understood the challenges they face in providing services to their clients. 

This project furthers anthropological theory and research on ways of knowing, health economics, alternative psychiatric practices, and dialogic ethnographic methods. The dissertation will contribute to current disciplinary conversations on "care", as well as problematizing commonly held notions of psychiatric crisis, expanding them to better tolerate the uncertainty embedded in severe mental illness. This work will also help to combat stigma against mental illness, and highlight the possibility for more human forms of intervention in psychiatric practice. This work will have an important impact on psychiatry and public health: the possibility for alternative understandings of psychiatric crisis, that emerge from long-term ethnographic engagement, stand to enrich the social and cultural perspectives on such conditions. It also provides detailed information about training, learning, economics, and community engagement that will make it easier to imagine alternative interventions. This project engages the lived experience of individuals and families negotiating the symptoms of severe mental illness. In approaching this topic from an open-ended and alternative perspective, the research offers a lens for de-stigmatizing the fear often associated with such conditions. Similarly, through the research project the co-PI collaborated with a number of psychiatrists and peer specialists who are involved in advocacy and policy work, and the research will be made useful in these contexts and in support of such efforts to improve global mental health.
